results.title: The Dehumanizing city...and Hymie Schultz
results.creator_credit: George Justin, Arthur Hiller, Learning Corporation of America and Colombia Pictures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Searching for values: a film anthology”.
Adapted from the film “The Tiger makes out” with Eli Wallach, the theme here is the modern individual in conflict with complex bureaucratic systems. Waking up one morning to the callous impersonality of big city life, Hymie Schultz, mailman, decides to fight back. Bureaucracy, however, proves more stubborn than he, and at the end of the day defeated and helpless, he retreats, one individual lost among many.

results.title: The Defiant ones
results.creator_credit: United Artists Corporation and Stanley Kramer
results.brief_description: Two convicts - one black, one white - escape across country chained together. Initially the yard of chain shackles two bitter enemies but gradually a bond grows between them. Dramatically and cinematically this is probably the most satisfying of Kramer’s “message” pictures but, although free of sentimentality and polemics, the notion of universal brotherhood is perhaps too simplistic to carry much conceptual interest. Winner of two Academy Awards (1958). Cast includes Tony Curtis and Sidney Poitier.

results.title: The Defensive driver
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Safe Driving”.
A father who accompanies his son on a short drive observes that his son is a safe driver who anticipates dangerous situations and drives defensively in order to avoid accidents. Father and son discuss driving hazards which require alertness and courtesy, as well as skill, on the part of drivers: overcrowded areas, complicated traffic lights, pedestrians, emergency vehicles, road signs, grade crossings, and student drivers.

results.title: The Deer hunter [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Universal Pictures, EMI/Parlophone, Barry Spikings, Michael Deeley, Michael Cimino and John Peverell
results.brief_description: The Deer hunter is a stunning epic exploration of the physical and psychological effects of the Vietnam War on three young working class men from a Pennsylvania steel town. The film is influenced by the sumptuous cinema of Visconti and Bertolluci, combining social observation with lavish tableaus of everyday life. From the opening wedding sequence to the nightmarish scenes in a prisoner of war camp, “The Deer Hunter” is a consistently astounding film that refuses to situate itself as either pro or anti War. Rather than tackling the specific history of the Vietnam war, it becomes instead a moving allegory on all war and on the destruction, it reaps on the psyches of both the victor and the conquered. “The Deer Hunter” won an Academy Award for Best Film and remains one of the best films ever made about war. With Robert De Niro, Christopher Walken, John Savage and Meryl Streep. The astonishing cinematography is by Vilmos Zsigmond.

results.title: The Deep frontier
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The 21st Century”.
An exploration of the ocean floor in a diving bell submarine that takes divers to an underwater residence for aquanauts. Among other devices shown are a four-story laboratory, a submarine with wheels and a remote controlled recovery robot. Interviews by Walter Cronkite with specialists in this area of research, including Jacques Cousteau, are featured also.

results.title: The Decline of western civilization
results.brief_description: Documentary filmed December 1979 through May 1980 in Los Angeles, California on the hard-core punk rock culture movement that existed at the time. Features a cross-section of some of the prominent Los Angeles bands performing live on stage at The Arena, The Fleetwood, Club 88, Hong Kong Cafe and Cherrywood Studios, including Alice Bag Band, Black Flag, Catholic Discipline, Circle Jerks, Fear, Germs, and X. Also includes some insightful interviews with members of the bands, punk fans and music industry moguls as they discuss their lives, the punk phenomenon and their philosophy on life. WARNING: Contains strong use of language and some violent scenes.

results.title: The Decline of the American empire = Le Declin de l'empire Americain
results.creator_credit: Corporation Image M and M, ONF | NFB, Rene Malo, Roger Frappier and Denys Arcand
results.brief_description: Denys Arcand (Jesus of Montreal, Love and human remains) wrote and directed this urbane comedy set in French Canada, about the sexual and intellectual life of eight adults. Four men (gay and straight) are gathered at a country retreat preparing a sumptuous dinner for themselves and four women. Over the course of the afternoon the men discuss sex, sexuality, affairs, fantasies, cruising, conquests, and longing unfulfilled. Meanwhile in the city four women, mostly the respective partners of the men, work out at a gym discussing sex, affairs, group sex, past lovers, s&m, and frustrations with their partners. The audience learns much about each character’s flaws, deceptions and secret lives. Flashback sequences reveal past indiscretions within the group, committed with one another. When all eight gather at dinner that night the openness displayed in the day spills into the evening activities and certain disclosures threaten the sanctity of the relationships of those gathered. Arcand examines the intellectual makeup of academics, the differences between men and women, the forces of sex and the politics of relationships. In French with English subtitles.
